importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date the article was updated, indicating the most current reporting on the issue of limited VA mental health therapy sessions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The policy shift to limit therapy sessions began under the administration of President Donald Trump, specifically after Doug Collins was appointed as VA Secretary in January 2025.

keyTakeAways: VA mental health providers and veterans report that one-on-one therapy sessions are being abruptly terminated or limited under new policy directives.

The policy, implemented under the Trump administration and enforced since January 2025, mandates that veterans receive a fixed number of therapy sessions (between 4 and 24), with no clinical discretion to extend care.
Providers say this approach undermines clinical judgment, especially for chronic conditions like PTSD, and can re-traumatize veterans who have developed trust with their therapists.
Some providers have resigned in frustration, including former VA psychologists Mark Jorges and Stephen Long, citing the policy as a violation of ethical and clinical standards.
Veterans like Michael and Jake Pannell express deep concern that abrupt termination of therapy leaves them without support during critical recovery phases.
The American Psychological Association has acknowledged reports and is investigating the issue, emphasizing the need for individualized, recovery-oriented, patient-provider shared decision-making.
The VA denies limiting sessions, claiming care is still open-ended and patient-centered, but providers and patients report otherwise.
Alternative options such as group therapy or re-application are offered, but many veterans find them unsuitable due to trauma, discomfort, or lack of continuity in care.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A growing number of VA mental health providers and veterans report that one-on-one therapy sessions are being abruptly limited or terminated under a new policy implemented since January 2025, under the leadership of VA Secretary Doug Collins, who was appointed during President Donald Trumpâ€™s administration. Veterans like Michael and Jake Pannell, who have long relied on sustained therapy for PTSD and trauma, describe feeling abandoned and re-traumatized when sessions are cut short without clinical justification. Providers such as Mark Jorges and Stephen Long have resigned or retired due to policy pressures, citing that such limits are inappropriate for chronic mental health conditions. While the VA claims there are no limits on sessions and that care is patient-centered, providers report they now must justify extensions in writing and face disciplinary consequences for pushing back. The American Psychological Association has acknowledged the reports and emphasized the need for individualized, recovery-oriented care. Critics argue that shortening therapy violates clinical standards and may worsen veteran outcomes, especially when patients need ongoing support.
title: VA Therapy Sessions Being Limited, Veterans and Providers Say
